name: Matthew Earl
tweet: @DonaldPond6 @TheFCA @BurfordCapital You seem to conflate issues & put words into people’s mouths. @TheFCA is perfectly capable of investigating suspected market manipulation. Who’s the “leading shorter” who said they’d never be investigated? If you believe that you’ll probably believe the return data $BUR provides.

name: Value Investigator
tweet: Prof Joshua Mitts finds evidence of market manipulation in the form of spoofing and layering causing an artificial decline in Burford’s share price around the @muddywatersre short attack. $BUR  https://t.co/UludiFFxKD

name: Matthew Earl
tweet: @goatinvesting Further, a court may not be persuaded that an NPO would be necessary for the applicant to obtain justice since @TheFCA would surely be the authority to prosecute market manipulation. Pursuant to success here, then $BUR would be in a stronger position to seek civil remedy.

name: Matthew Earl
tweet: @goatinvesting It doesn’t seem that clear cut. The decision looks to be based on view that claimant would be a “data recipient” and not a “data controller”. So it’ll be interesting to see whether future cases pick up on this distinction. Either way still appears $BUR has the horse before cart.

name: Goatinvesting
tweet: #BUR #BURFORD $BUR

name: Matthew Earl
tweet: 2/ Strikes me that $BUR is seeking to perform the role of regulator, which it is not commissioned to do. Order of events should be for @TheFCA to determine if market manipulation has occurred & then for any such Norwich Pharmacal relief to be sought against that smaller data set.

name: Matthew Earl
tweet: 1/ Burford’s $BUR Norwich Pharmacal relief application looks a little flimsy to me. I suspect given the amount of personal data requested that it will undoubtedly face serious obstacles, least of all from a GDPR perspective.

name: Do The Maths
tweet: @RodriGo_ethe On the P/B multiple itself, I would argue that Burford deserves a big premium because (i) the company is smaller (and can therefore grow faster), (ii) book value has historically compounded at a rapid rate (owing to high IRRs + high deployment velocity). (2/2)  $BUR #BUR

name: Do The Maths
tweet: @RodriGo_ethe Most big public PE funds (think BAM, KKR, APO) trade at ~1x  book value +15-20x fee-related earnings [base fees] + 5-10x carry [performance fees]. So, right from the get go, 1x book probably undervalues the company as it ignores external capital (1/2)  $BUR #BUR

tweet: Burford Capital CEO on the growth prospects of the business. $BUR  https://t.co/MquEwJPWGv

name: Rodrigo Benedetti
tweet: Things on $BUR that I got wrong:  - It's not an operating company. PER (Not even using realised gains only) is not a right value metric, but book value. Would you invest in Softbank/PSH at 3-4x book?

name: Do The Maths
tweet: P.S. Any law firm which refers to itself as a "top-ranked law firm" almost certainly isn't.   $BUR #BUR

name: Do The Maths
tweet: I'm yet to see evidence that Burford has mis-marked investments or manipulated returns. Without this, what case against the company do these class actions have?  $BUR #BUR

name: Do The Maths
tweet: As far as I can tell, the complaints just parrot the original Muddy Waters allegations, most of which (at least in my view) have been debunked - e.g. the silly claim that Burford is "arguably insolvent".    $BUR #BUR

name: Do The Maths
tweet: It's disappointing to see so much pearl-clutching over the class actions against Burford. These are fairly par for the course following big share price movements, especially in the USA.    $BUR #BUR

name: yZyy
tweet: Assessing SITG is a highly subjective matter and I could have a different opinion about it than you, even if we studied the same data.  I'm open to discussion about any matter regarding the business and feel free to correct any mistakes in my work.  Have a good one. $BUR

name: yZyy
tweet: There are 2 different components to SITG in this case:  (a) SITG with $BUR shareholders. (b) SITG with $BUR managed funds investors.  As a conclusion, I think management is potentially fulfilling both (a) & (b) and I'm not as worried as before about (a).

name: yZyy
tweet: Now, for $BUR, we are clearly in a combined situation of 2 and 3. Management can choose to invest in the company by purchasing stock or investing in the funds they manage. Spanish AM companies' managers have to choose between 1 and 3, and they typically do the later.

name: yZyy
tweet: Considering the pressumed net worth, we can divide that into the cash they received from selling stock in '18 and their current position in $BUR. Take this into account, we can see that they could, at very max, be holding LESS than their net worth in cash.

name: yZyy
tweet: First, let me start with a disclaimer: I currently hold a LONG position in $BUR. Also, I have to thank @ancirrel for an eye-opening clue about the management's SITG which I was only suspecting about prior to his help.  (Lastly, apologies for broken englando lol)

name: Condorito
tweet: A long morning thinking about Investment processes and what I learn with the #BUR  $BUR case and with the Muddy Waters report. These are my thoughts, a long thread, I am just sharing my thoughts:

name: Andrew Nash
tweet: @DoTheMaths1 The $BUR way obtains a higher net realised gain and lower fair value movement. $BUR highlight net realised/fair value split as a metric. If it had been 10/90 for example, people might have been more queasy. Price action indicates people didn't get the story.

name: jᎾsᎬ ᏒᎾᎠᏒᎥᎶuᎬᏃ 
tweet: @AccionEAFI @rubescudero @bolsamania 👏🏽👏🏽👏🏽👏🏽 así hay que actuar, coloquialmente.... con dos “cojon...”! A ver si $BUR hace lo mismo.

name: Andrew Nash
tweet: @DoTheMaths1 Maybe. But was it prudent? It seems like $BUR were aggressive here.

name: LST
tweet: as $BUR shares are trading around book value, it gives the marginal buyer/seller the opportunity to appraise its business. It also gives the company a chance to perform on its merits, without the ridiculous advantage the market was affording them when it was trading much higher.

name: LST
tweet: more later, but I think the topics I'm addressing: what is $BUR 's underlying business and how does one go about understanding its accounting? These always should have been the priorities for investors. Not too late, as shares are now trading more or less around book value.

name: LST
tweet: it's not just that a cash based accounting would severely understate a litfin business's earnings, it would provide little to no informational value to the financial statements' users... which is not good for investors.  so accrual based accounting is the least worst option. $BUR

name: LST
tweet: Why can't accounting accurately portray litigation finance dynamics?   Suppose a litigation finance firm, $BUR or anyone, adopted the most "conservative" accounting policies. Cash based accounting. This adoption would severely understate the true earnings power of the business.

name: LST
tweet: So if you understand $BUR / Burford's business (read prior tweets first), what does this mean for the accounting?  I don't think accounting is designed to capture these nonlinear dynamics. I think there's no way accounting can accurately portray litigation finance dynamics.  why?

name: LST
tweet: I am of the belief that $BUR intrinsic value is unknowable with any degree of confidence, standard deviation, for all the reasons I have outlined today. You can't discredit nor unduly credit the 0.01% payoffs, because it's in the business of being positioned for those payoffs.

name: Alvaro Gomez de Olea
tweet: Respuestas que espero de $BUR: - Listing en Nasdaq / LSE Main - Directivos compran acciones - Recompra de acciones - Rating de Moody’s / S&P - Mayor detalle en retornos por caso (ya hecho) - Mejora de la comunicación con accionista (trimestral, casos con retornos elevados)

name: LST
tweet: is litigation finance - i.e. $BUR Burford - a good or bad business?  on the other hand  2. the risk vs reward, the cost to expected proceeds... this is highly skewed positive, the asymmetry i mentioned earlier (fixed cost vs wildly nonlinear payoffs) is quite notable.

name: LST
tweet: So given that $BUR is the sum of its interests in litigations (and ability to invest in future ones), is litigation finance a good or bad business? I won't go into all considerations, but here's food for thought:   1, $BUR true profits are inherently lumpy, timing unpredictable

name: LST
tweet: Said differently about $BUR : there is an “80/20” type dynamic in play, whereby 20% of your litigations will account for 80% of proceeds. This is a feature, not bug. Whether you’re bearish/bullish, these observations must be your starting point to before you analyse accounting.
